Intervention: Fixed appliance ((rapid expansion) banded Hyrax (tooth borne))
Comparison: Fixed appliance ((rapid expansion) banded Hyrax (tooth/tissue borne))
Reasons for GRADE if not High: 2 studies (1 high risk of bias; 1 unclear), which were not possible to pool in a meta analysis due to no reporting of variance in 1 study. Imprecision due to low sample sizes. Different timings of follow up after completion of expansion. Both studies reported no difference in molar expansion

Intervention: Fixed appliance ((rapid expansion) banded Hyrax (tooth borne))
Comparison: Fixed appliance ((rapid expansion) banded Hyrax (tooth/tissue borne))
Outcome: Molar expansion (3 months after completion of expansion phase)
Reasons for GRADE if not High: 2 studies at unclear risk of bias with serious inconsistency (I2 = 94%) and imprecision due to low sample size

Intervention: Fixed appliance ((rapid expansion) banded Hyrax (tooth borne))
Comparison: Fixed appliance ((rapid expansion) banded Hyrax (tooth/tissue borne))
Reasons for GRADE if not High: The remaining comparisons were all single studies (Additional Table 1). The quality of the evidence (GRADE) for all comparisons and outcomes in Additional Table 1 is very low (all at unclear or high risk of bias with imprecision due to low sample sizes). None of these studies showed a statistically significant difference for any outcome.

Outcome: Crossbite correction (Follow up after retention period, therefore, it was variable)
Reasons for GRADE if not High: 2 studies at low risk of bias, but with serious inconsistency (I2 = 68%) and imprecision due to low sample size

Outcome: Molar expansion (mm) (Follow up after retention period, therefore, it was variable)
Reasons for GRADE if not High: 2 studies at low risk of bias, but with imprecision due to low sample size

Outcome: Canine expansion (mm) (Follow up after retention period, therefore, it was variable)
Reasons for GRADE if not High: 2 studies at low risk of bias, but with serious inconsistency (I2 = 91%) and imprecision due to low sample size

1 of the 2 studies in this comparison also measured stability of crossbite correction (relapse 12 months after correction). No statistically significant difference was found (Additional Table 2). The other study also compared the fixed and removable appliances to composite onlays for crossbite correction, molar expansion and canine expansion. All results were statistically significant in favour of fixed and removable appliances (Additional Table 2). The quality of the evidence (GRADE) for all comparisons and outcomes in Additional Table 2 is very low.
